debateinfo.title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (YOUTH ALLOWANCE) BILL 1997

talk.start.para: âThe committee is considering the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 and request No. 11 on sheet 866 moved by Senator Margetts. The question is that the request for an amendment be agreed to.
âI would like to ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) to clarify what constitutes a breach under the activity test.

âI think I gave you an answer to this question on Thursday. Did I not provide you with an answer to that? I remember I had a discussion with Senator Neal about the penalty rates for breaches that we did by negotiation in early 1997. The activity test breaches include where a person who is required to satisfy an activity test fails to do so or fails to satisfy any requirements relating to youth allowance activity agreements that apply to the person under subdivision (e) of division 1; where the person has refused or failed without reasonable excuse to accept a suitable offer of employment; where the person refuses or fails without reasonable excuse to provide information in relation to the person's income from remunerative work when required to do so; where the person knowingly or recklessly provides false or misleading information in relation to their income when required to do so. It goes on from there. There is nothing extraordinary about them. They are not what you might be driving at, which I would call administrative breaches.

âMinister, you mentioned `failed to satisfy any requirements', and that was fairly early in the list. There were some more deliberate points on the list later on, but failing to satisfy any of the requirements could be a technical breach. I know it says the third breach, but notification of a breach might not actually reach the person. How would a person know, for instance, that they had breached once or twice? For instance, if they breached once and they had been notified but their address was not accurate, could it not be possible that they could breach more than once and not know that they had breached?
âSenator, I do not think you could have been in the chamber when this was all discussed very thoroughly.
âI was in the chamber.

âNot just last Thursday but also when we were changing the requirements for breaches a year or more ago. You will recall that under the previous government people were breached by losing their payment immediately regardless. We have changed that. We negotiated that with the parties in the Senate last year to a rate reduction for a number of weeks for the first penalty, a bigger rate reduction for the second penalty and only on the third breach do people lose all payment altogether. Have you forgotten that?

âI think it was established during those debates, however, that some of those breaches could have still been technical breaches. Even though a person lost their benefit, there may still be something which was out of the person's control. What I am specifically asking about is whether there is any discretion involved here. If there was no discretion involved in the previous applications of the term penalties or breaches, how can you say that a person will not be treated unfairly? Is there any discretion involved in the definition of breaches? Can a person judgeâeven if there are three breachesâ whether or not a person has been treated fairly?

âI think Senator Margetts, in talking about technical breaches, is referring to administrative breaches which are regarded as a lesser order, like not returning a form on time, for example. There is no discretion, as I understand it, as to whether something is determined to be an administrative breach, which gets a lesser penalty, and an activity test breach, which has the penalties that I just spelled out to you. It is very important to understand that there are two kinds of breaches: one is less serious and the other group is more serious.

speech.para: The officers do not have an opportunity to distinguish between those two. If it is an administrative breach, one lot of rules apply. If it is an activity test breach, another lot of rules apply. Within that area people who are not satisfied with the decision of the determining officer have the right to ask for a review, which is done by an authorised review officer, an ARO. If that is still not satisfactory, people can then go to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

talk.start.para: âThe minister is indicating that, without any means of support, a person may be expected to ask for a review. How long would the review take?

âMr Chairman, I think it must be made very clear to Senator Margetts that, as compared with the past, people are not nowâwith unemployment payments, for exampleâbeing left with no means support, unless it is the third time they have broken the law.

âI really do not feel that the minister's answer has been satisfactory. If there is no ability for discretion, you will findâand I know the courts in Western Australia who have `three strikes and you are out' legislation find it extremely difficult when an arbitrary number is pulled out of the air with it being said, `Okay, if you've done something three times, you must be punished in a certain way,' and this is punitiveâthere will always, always be circumstances where, no matter how many times you arbitrarily decide, there will be people for whom no one of those breaches is their fault; that there are reasons why they were unable to avoid those things.

speech.para: There are reasons sometimes of poverty, there are reasons of family tragedy. There are a whole range of reasons, of circumstances, where pulling out an arbitrary number of three times will be unfair if there are no discretions. And, if there are no discretions, what is the basis upon which a person might appeal?

talk.start.para: âThere is discretion and in the sorts of circumstances you are talking aboutâlike family tragedy, illness, et ceteraâthe officers are entitled to use that discretion. Senator, you were part of this chamber that put that measure through last year as a non-controversial piece of legislation.
âI am actually referring to the part in this bill in relation to the activity test breach; I asked you a little while ago, `Was it discretionary?' and you said no. That is what I am referring to.
âAs between the two kinds of breaches.

âThe minister is saying that there is a different sort of breach, but in this instance, the minister is saying that it is not discretionary. I am asking: on what basis, for a non-discretionary clause to be in this bill, would a person be able to appeal?

âMr Chairman, I do not think Senator Margetts listened carefully to the answer. There are activity breaches which are the more serious ones and carry a more serious penalty, and there are administrative breaches which are considered to be less serious and carry a less serious penalty. So it is determined by law which is which.
âYou are writing the law.

âHowever, Senatorâif you would listen instead of jumping to conclusionsâwithin each of those two areas of breaches, the departmental officials are able to exercise their discretion. There is also, as I pointed out to you, an extensive review mechanism. I think that the Senate regarded that as fair. You are saying to me that we are talking about this legislation. Yes, we are. But it is mirroring the legislation that the Senate signed on to last year as a piece of non-controversial legislation. So I find it strange that you are revisiting an issue that the Senate has already passed judgment on.

âI think Senator Newman may be stepping on very dangerous ground if she starts talking about non-controversial legislation, when I am basically abused nearly every time the Greens have problems with a piece of so-called non-controversial legislation which often we have not had much chance to look at.

speech.para: So, if at any time we pass something through and are asked sometimes to have about two or three days to look at a piece of legislation, if then you are going to come back and say, `You agreed to it because we passed it through quickly in a lunchtime,' then I would suggest that you do not try to do that; you will not get any more pieces of legislation through at lunchtime. If we do not get a chance to look carefully at legislation, then it is quite reasonable for the Greens to say, `No, we're not going to do them in lunchtimes.' If you are then going to turn around to us and say, `We gave you a lunchtime to look at it,' or `We gave you this amount of time; we pleaded with you because we want it in a non-controversial Thursday,' I think you are stepping on very dangerous ground.

talk.start.para: âI think Senator Margetts cannot have taken any notice or any interest in the issue when it came before the Senate last time. It came about that that legislation was changed because, in the debate in December 1996, Senator Harradine suggested that he could see that all the parties around the chamber were trying to grasp at a solution which would be fairer than the system we inherited, which took people off payments altogether regardless of their offence. We were agreeable to that. So we did as was suggested by Senator Harradine. We went around to the parties with some proposals, and we negotiated the final outcome of that piece of non-controversial legislation which was passed by the Senate with due process.

speech.para: Now, suddenly, you are just discovering it. I am sorry about that. But what we have in this legislation is a mirror image of what the Senate thoughtfully decided upon previously.

talk.start.para: âIf Senator Newman is suggesting that the Greens (WA) agreeing to an improvement on something that was bad means that we still agree with the bad points or unfair points of the legislation, that is not true. If you want to continue on with this kind of nonsense argument, Senator, please do. But please do not assume that, when we vote for an improvement on something that is ghastly, that means we believe that the ghastly thing is okay.

âThe Democrats will be supporting the Greens (WA) amendment in relation to the substitution of two weeks instead of eight weeks. Although I take on board the senator's comments about previous legislative changes in relation to the breach period, we do note that when the government first came to power the penalty for the breach of the activity test was two to six weeks for a first breach, and then subsequent breaches attracted a penalty of the period of the first breach plus an additional six weeks. So we prefer the amendment as put forward by the Greens WA.

âI do want to make a few comments about this amendment and also about a view expressed by the minister when we were here on Thursday afternoon. There was some discussion when the breaches of the activity test were first put in place. But I thought it was going a little bit far to say that there was an `agreement', as if it were an initiative jointly of the government and the opposition.

speech.para: It would be more accurate to say that the government proposed penalties for breaches of the activity test we found quite unacceptable. I suppose we were happy that the government was agreeable to negotiating a penalty that was less severe. To some extent we negotiated down the initial penalty. I suppose it can be described as agreement, but probably not to the full extent that might have been drawn from what the minister said. Certainly, the ultimate result was brought about by negotiation between the opposition, the government and other members.

Bearing that in mind, the opposition does not intend to support this amendment. We do see it as obviously a balance between ensuring that the penalties are not so severe that people find their circumstances quite untenable, and ensuring that people accept that they do have a responsibility to comply with the requirements for the payment of their benefits or their benefits will be suspended for a period.
We believed at the time of the negotiation that this was a reasonable balance. Nothing has occurred that has altered our minds on this and accordingly we will not be supporting these changes.

talk.start.para: âCan I ask the minister a simple question, and forgive me if it is too simple? My understanding is that under this bill people could void the non-payment period by taking up work under the work for the dole program. Would those people presumably be included in the voluntary work for the dole participants?

âI am advised that for young people who go into the work for the dole scheme, whether it is voluntary or whether it is because they are directed to, if they have a breach penalty outstanding, that is waived.

âI am just assuming that those people, by virtue of volunteering to void the non-payment period, would be included in the voluntary numbers. Presumably, if they volunteer to get involved for whatever reason, including voiding that non-payment period, they would be included in the voluntary work for the dole.
âI am advised that that is that DEETYA classification and we are really not in a position to be able to give you a precise answer. I have given you the best answer that I can at this stage.
âThe question is that the request for an amendment be agreed to.

interjection.para: Request not agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: (10) Schedule 1, item 6, page 52 (after line 29), after subsection 550C(1), insert:
(1A) A notice under subsection (1) must contain reasons why the activity test non-payment period applies to the person.

talk.start.para: âThe government will accept Senator Margetts' amendment.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(12) Schedule 1, item 6, page 65 (lines 25 and 26), omit "one or more of sections 553A to 553C", substitute "either or both of sections 553B and 553C".
(13) Schedule 1, item 6, page 66 (line 1) to page 67 (line 4), omit section 553A.
This amendment refers to clause 553A, subsection (2) of the bill on page 66, which states:
If:
(a) a person's unemployment was due to other people being, or having been, engaged in industrial act or in a series of industrial actions; and
(b) the people, or some of the people, were members of a trade union that was involved in the industrial action;
the person is subject to an employment-related exclusion unless the person satisfies the Secretary that the person was not a member of the trade union during the person's period of the unemployment.

I find that a fairly discriminatory clause. Basically, it says that, if there has been industrial action which has caused a person to lose their job or to be unemployed, they are going to be punished. Not only have they been disadvantaged from losing their job or because they felt it necessary to take industrial actionâso there must be have been some problem to start withâbut they are going to be punished for being involved with a union or being a member of a union. There is the word `and' in here. It states:
. . . the people, or some of the people, were members of a trade union that was involved in the industrial action;. . .
The minister will no doubt say that there are other bills to which this applies. We think this stinks, whichever bill you put it in.

talk.start.para: âThis is mirroring an existing provision which has been presided over by the last Labor government for the last 13 years. The presence of the trade union reference is not new to us. Our legislation is simply replicating the provisions in the newstart allowance legislation, with some minor changes due to the different qualification conditions.

speech.para: Also it is not believed that it will affect significant numbers of people as most people will return to work after industrial action. The point about the preclusion period which I think is important to understand is that it applies only to industrial action which is in breach of an order, direction or injunction issued by a state industrial authority, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or the Federal Court. So, it is only if the industrial action is in breach of that that this period applies.

Before the six-week preclusion period was introduced difficulties used to arise in determining the exact reasons for a person's unemployment while the issues surrounding the industrial action remained unresolved. Now the preclusion period allows resolution of issues. This is simply a transfer of the provisions in the newstart allowance legislation that we inherited into youth allowance. There is nothing particularly sinister because the words `trade union' are in the amendment.

talk.start.para: âThe minister has not been quite fulsome in her response in as much as things have been changed. Yes, this connection with newstart did exist under the previous government, but the minister has forgotten to remind the chamber that there have been many changes in the industrial relations law since then. There are very few areas which are considered to be legal industrial action any more, and more and more the industrial courts are restricted in enabling people to take industrial action. So things have changed. It is totally inappropriate to continue to put this kind of clause in any bill.

speech.para: I would like to think the Labor Party will also consider that membership of a union in relation to youth allowance would not be the means by which people are discriminated and singled out, because so many things have changed. We all know how very few issues this government thinks can be acceptable for industrial action. During that debate we had issues like workers' health and safety which was so limited as to make workplaces dangerous. We know that people could not include meal breaks as allowable matters in their awards.

So many things have changed not only as a result of the federal legislation but also as a result of enabling state legislation that have made things even more restrictive. In Western Australia they are talking about fourth and fifth wave industrial legislation to make it harder and harder for people in the workplace to organise and for people to be engaged in anything that might in any way, shape or form be considered a legal strike or industrial action. The minister was not quite accurate when she said that this provision is the same as it has been before because the whole nature of industrial relations has changed since we dealt with this provision previously. I would say that, at the very least, it is now totally inappropriate.

talk.start.para: âThe Democrats will support this amendment because of a number of concerns we have with the clause. I acknowledge the minister's comments in relation to similar provisionsâas did Senator Dee Margettsâbut I share the same concerns that Senator Margetts has just outlined. While there may be provisions similar to clause 553A that have already been enactedâand I think an example is section 596 of the Social Security ActâI am very concerned, as are my Democrat colleagues, that this sort of provision is inconsistent both with a number of existing laws and with our understanding of internationally recognised labour laws and labour rights.

speech.para: The clear imputation of proposed section 553A is that if you are unemployed because you are involved in industrial action, then you bear the onus of proof of satisfying the department that you were not a member of the trade union. I am curious as to whether this is your reading too, Senator Margetts, but I believe this is inconsistent with the Workplace Relations Act which specifically protects the right to take industrial action in some circumstances. It is arguably inconsistent with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which says that everyone has the right to freedom of association with others and that that right should not be restricted. I think this provision, along with a number of others, is a particularly sinister provision and it is one we should reject in this bill. Therefore, we will be supporting the amendment before us.

talk.start.para: âI have just sought to obtain a copy of the act. Would the minister detail whether or not the current provision that is proposed in clause 553A differs in any way from the provisions currently in the legislation for newstart allowance; and, if so, in what manner does it differ?

âI have just been advised that there are some slight word ing differences but that the effect is exactly the same. Perhaps I should also add that with the preclusion period changes to newstart a year agoâwe are talking about the comparability of that legislation hereâthe government agreed to incorporate the Democrat amendments restricting the application of the preclusion period to the above circumstances only. Those circumstances are the ones I read out earlier that were inserted by the Democrats amendments with the acceptance of the government.

speech.para: Nothing that we are doing here is different in effect from what happens now to newstart allowance. It is most undesirable, as Senator Bartlett has said a few times in this debate, that there be great variation between the way that various payments are administered. If you are going to worry, as I would, about mistakes being made by staff, about uncertainties and confusion as to people's entitlements or as to how they will be treated, then you do not try to vary these basic requirements if you can possibly help it. I cannot think of any justifiable reason why you would have different requirements for the newstart allowance from those for the youth allowance for the same activity.

talk.start.para: âThe minister is somewhat inconsistent here. She is quite happy to treat young people differently when it comes to saving money for the government and has done so with this particular measure and series of measures. The minister cannot be serious about being consistent, because she is prepared to single out a group of people and say, `No, you can't get unemployment benefits and you can't get case studies if we decide that you are of the wrong age or wrong category.' When it is convenient, the minister is quite capable of singling out a group of people and disadvantaging them.

speech.para: Minister, is it not young people who are less likely to be able to make agreements or negotiate by themselves? Are we not picking out young people and saying, `We don't want you to be part of a union; this is one of those cases where we are going to disadvantage young people for being part of a union'? I am very keen to find out what the Labor Party's response to this is, considering that they, more than anyone else, should be aware of what kinds of changes have occurred between the time of the legislation that they were involved with and now, considering the change in the industrial climate in Australia. I ask whether the Labor Party is going to respond.

talk.start.para: âEssentially, the waiting period requirement was introduced by the then Labor government. This bill seems to take bits and pieces out of the waiting period on a fairly ad hoc basis. It is really not going to assist people who are trying to access the benefits. Obviously, a great deal of uncertainty and confusion about the issue is of no particular assistance. The opposition thinks that retaining some certainty and clarity in the way the waiting period operates is the most important factor.

âI find it extraordinary that we are singling out and penalising a group of people for being members of a union. We are talking about subclause 553A(2) of the bill. We are saying that unemployment due to industrial action means that a person has to wait longer to get any benefit. So we are not talking about the normal waiting period. That is why I want to know whether the Labor Party still thinks this is acceptable, considering the changes that have occurred in the industrial climate in Australia that mean there are so few areas considered by this government, under legislation, to be valid industrial action. Basically, this is not the normal waiting period; this is a penalty for people for being members of a union which has taken industrial action.

âAs to that view which has been put by Senator Margetts, I would be grateful if the minister would clarify whether the waiting period for unemployed individuals who were involved in industrial action is consistent with that for those who are not working for a genuine reason.

âThe consistency is that the existing legislation for newstart allowance has a preclusion period for people who are engaged in unlawful industrial disputes. I read out that, where there has been a breach of an order, direction or injunction issued by a state industrial authority, the Industrial Relations Commission or the Federal Court of Australia, the customer will be subject to an employment related preclusion period for youth allowance for a period of six weeks from the date the industrial action ceases. They are slightly different words, but I am advised that it has exactly the same effect as that for the newstart allowance, which was amended with some amendments from the Democrats to that effect last year. It was a continuation of giving industrial action special treatment in the previous legislation, but it has been ameliorated somewhat.
âI am trying to discover whether someone who is involved in industrial actionâ
âUnlawful.
âunlawful industrial action has a longer waiting period than someone who is just unemployed.

âIt is a bit difficult to answer because there are all sorts of waiting periods for different purposes depending on people's financial circumstances. Some waiting periods would be longer and some would be much shorter. It is about in the middle.

âTo put some perspective on this, I remind the Senate that during the industrial relations debate the Greens (WA) pointed out that if, for instance, there was a dangerous situation at a workplace and those people in the workplace, other than the person who is specifically put in the dangerous situation, took industrial action in support of the person who is in that dangerous situation, under this government that would be considered unlawful industrial action.

speech.para: There is a whole range of what I believe to be unfair circumstances which are now considered to be unlawful industrial actions. They could be trying to save the lives, or the future lives and health, of your fellow workers. The government's industrial relations legislation says that only the person or persons being put in that position of danger can take lawful industrial action. They could be told to move on and put someone else in until someone is found who does not have the courage to stand up for themselves. Basically, we are talking about a whole range of issues which did not exist beforeâincluding trying to save the lives of your fellow workers.

talk.start.para: âMinister, I was not completely clear on the answer you gave before. You said that the waiting period varies depending on the person's financial circumstancesâwhich I acceptâbut in the case of two people who are in identical financial situations, in terms of their liquid assets and other things, and one person is unemployed because they have been dismissed and another person is unemployed because of what is called unlawful industrial action, is the waiting period different?

âI am just double-checking with the minister. Subclause 4 talks about industrial action in breach of order, direction or injunction, but subclauses 1, 2 and 3 actually relate to being engaged in industrial action, other people engaged in industrial action and length of employment related exclusion. Only clause 4 relates to unlawful industrial action. In fact, clauses 1, 2 and 3 relate to any kind of industrial action. If a person loses their job as a result of any kind of industrial actionâthat is the clause we are talking about, clause 2âthen, Minister, you could be misleading the Senate if you are relating only to unlawful industrial action, couldn't you?

âMr Chairman, can I just help again here? If you are involved in industrial action which is not unlawful you obviously do not get unemployment benefits while you are engaged in industrial action but you go back onto payments as soon as that action ends. If you are engaged in industrial action which is unlawful on the basis of those specific decisions that I referred to earlier from the Industrial Relations Commission, the Federal Court, a state industrial authority, et cetera, then you must wait six weeks. However, if you have any outstanding waiting periods which you are liable forâand maybe you were trying to ask me this, Senatorâyou serve them concurrently. You wait six weeks if you have been engaged in unlawful industrial action, but you serve that six weeks concurrently with anything else that you might be liable for.

âThere is a situation here where a person is unemployedânot a person being on strike, we are talking about a person's unemployment. Those are the words of the bill. It relates to when a person's unemploymentâthat is, losing their jobâis due to other people being, or having been, engaged in industrial action. So we have established now that we are not necessarily talking about illegal industrial action. We are in clause 4, but clauses 1, 2 and 3 are talking about any kind of industrial action.

speech.para: We are talking about a person who has lost their job as a result, some way or another, of industrial action. In fact, what you are saying, but need to clarify, is that if a person has lost their job for one reason or another as a result of industrial actionâlawful or unlawfulâthey will still be subject to this penalty clause.

talk.start.para: âThe question isâ
âIf the minister is going to answer that question, I would prefer it being in Hansard rather than from the chair.
âIt is not a matter of answering the question, Senator Margetts. I only call people who are standing and the minister was not standing. That is why I put the question.
âThat is what I am suggesting would be reasonable. As the minister has made specific statements before, it is not unreasonable for her to put her response in Hansard rather than from her seat.

âSenator Margetts, I hesitated to get up and take the time of the Senate again because I just told you specifically: if somebody is engaged in industrial action which is not deemed unlawful, they are eligible for unemployment payments as soon as the industrial action ends.
âI will just refer the minister to page 65 of the bill under `Employment-related exclusions'. It states:

The truth is that you are trying to force an election on this issue because loony left wing senators like Senator Bolkus actually think you can get some crazy advantage out of forcing an election on this issue. You are dead wrong. You ought to support this bill.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, is it true that the government has now walked away from its commitment that all unemployed people, whether on benefits or not, will be able to access the services of the new employment service agencies? Here we have unemployment in the low eights. We have introduced a new jobs network system which is going to work and unemployed people will not be turned away. âMy question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the minister to reports that the right to negotiate process in the Native Title Act is causing serious delays to resource projects. Would the minister update the Senate on the impact that the statutory right to negotiate process is having on Australia's resources sector?

âFigures released today by the Bureau of Resource Sciences show that exploration discoveries in oil and gas achieved record levels in 1997. Fifty-five petroleum discoveries were made in totalâ43 onshore and 12 off the coast of north-west of Australia. Total petroleum exploration expenditure last year reached $1 billion and included the drilling of more than 100 exploration wells.

answer.para: I announced today that applications will be issued for 58 offshore exploration permits under the work bidding program, which will ensure that the strong exploration discovery rate continues. This high level of oil and gas exploration is absolutely vital to bolster our domestic energy supplies and sustain strong economic growth, employment, exports and investment.

But there is a major impediment to the continued growth in the resources sector, and that is Labor's unworkable Native Title Act; a fact that is supported unequivocally by APPEA, the mining council, AMEC and the prospectors. Australia's Mining Monthly magazine recently published a survey of Australia's largest exploration companies. The survey highlights the act's disastrous impact on the resources sector. The survey shows that the risk of exploring in Australia is relatively low. Coalition policies are working and are appreciated by the wealth creating resources industry.

But we have the world's worst rating in terms of land claims. Simply because of the Native Title Act, it is riskier to explore in Australia than in countries like Peru, Ghana or India. It is hardly surprising that Australian resource companies are directing their exploration dollars overseas.
While already of great concern, the Australian economy has not yet felt the full effects of the uncertainty created by the act because of the long lead times involved in resource projects.

One estimate is that the Native Title Act is costing Australia about $30 billion in mining revenue, delays and lost investment opportunities. The government's concerns about the Native Title Act have now been confirmed by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in a board report which states:

The fact is that mining leases are being held up in the right to negotiate process. Some 1,913 of the 2,094 tenements submitted to the process remain subject to negotiation. Furthermore, the rate of objections by the native title parties to the grant of the exploration licences is starting to increase significantly which means further delays.
That is from ATSIC.

The Native Title Act is totally unworkable. The farmers know it; the miners know it; the petroleum industry knows it; the Labor Party knows it; and the Australian people know it. It is about time the weak Leader of the Opposition showed some backbone and leadership and told the noisy left wing of his party to go jump and support the government's amendments which he knows will benefit all Australians, including farmers, miners and Aborigines.

talk.start.para: âCould the minister further detail to the Senate the way the Native Title Act has worked in practice on the minerals and energy resources sector?

âThe supplementary question should more correctly have been: how has the Native Title Act not worked? These are the facts on our great resource industries. Firstly, no negotiations have been completed in Australia within the statutory time periods. Numerous overlapping claimsâas Senator Minchin said, 42 separate claimsâon some mineral applications make negotiations virtually impossible.

answer.para: In Western Australia alone more than 2,000 mineral applications are held up by the right to negotiate process, some for almost three years, and the backlog is growing by 14 new claims a week. Only 183 voluntary agreements have been registered by the tribunal in Western Australia and only 56 mining leases granted. Before the Native Title Act was enacted, between 600 and 800 mining leases were granted each year in Western Australia.

talk.start.para: âAnd pay for it.

âYou don't understand, do you?

answer.para: It is a tragedy for this nation that the left wing of the Labor Partyâ

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, could you explain why out of the Employment Services Regulatory Authority's 15 top performing providers of assistance to long-term unemployed peopleâall 15 of which were in the top 10 per cent nationallyâonly four got government contracts under the supposedly new and improved employment services market? Is this not yet another indication that this whole exercise has turned into an utter shambles?

âHere we go again. Over 1,000 choices were made available to this government in this huge tender process which involved a cost of $1.7 billion. What we looked at was not necessarily the organisations themselves but the sites that could be serviced. Some organisations which had a particular knowledge of a certain site could put forward a very good tender. Obviously some organisations, whilst good organisations, did not have that same relevance to the particular site in question. Therefore it was that we picked the best tender for the best particular site.

answer.para: That did not mean to say that all the top organisations necessarily had to be successful. That is why out of the 1,000-odd that I have mentioned just over 300 were successfulâit was a highly competitive tender. It did not mean to say that we just went out, followed ESRA and said, `Okay, who are your top 14; we'll give them a job.' We went through each tender meticulouslyâin fact, more than once. It was a blind tender process, where the identities of people were not known. Also, it was governed by Blake Dawson Waldron, a very large firm of solicitors, who were there as probity advisers from day one.

So what we had was one of the best tender processes Australia has ever seen. It was certainly the biggest by way of services. The amount of $1.7 billion really put it up there as one of the biggest tenders any government has pursued. I say to you, Senator O'Brien, that it was not a question of our just going out to ESRA or somebody and saying, `Who do you think we should give this tender to?' It was a case of going through a methodical process to ensure that we gave the tender to the best person. In this case, it was a very good tender process indeed, and it is now paying dividends to the people of Australia.

Since you insist on defending your system, perhaps you can explain how Queensland company, Allhands Hire Pty Ltd, was selected to provide employment services when it had financial problems with unprofitable contracts and was put up for sale only days after DEETYA informed the company of its success in the tender process. Great scheme, Minister!

âThis is another question which was just put to the minister concerned in the other placeâDr Kemp. I am unaware of the details of this particular matter, but I understand that Dr Kemp has undertaken to look into the matter. We will look into any matter which you seek to raise. Perhaps you have some documents there you would like to table which would assist us in investigating this matter. We had supervision by accountants when we looked at the viability of these tenderers. In that regard, the process was indeed a meticulous one.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to his response to my question last Tuesday relating to the Federation Fund in which he indicated he was `not at liberty to provide information on what the government might be considering it would do'. I also note that, at a public meeting in Northampton on 19 February 1998, the Hon. Kevin Minson MLA stated that the proposed Oakajee development was `on the Prime Minister's list of six, I think, major projects that the federal government wants to see go ahead'. At the same meeting, Dr Alan Tingay, consultant to An Feng, said that Oakajee was `on the Prime Minister's list of six major projects that need to be established'. What was the source of Mr Minson's and Dr Tingay's information? Is this information correct and, if so, does this wish list relate to Commonwealth funding from the Federation Fund, or is it to come from some other source?

âI think the honourable senator is a little confused about this matter. As I understand it, we are speaking about two major projects which to some extent are interrelated. The first is the An Feng Kingstream Steel Ltd proposal to construct a steel processing plant near Geraldton, Western Australia. I am told the investment would be about $1.4 billion and would generate around 650 full-time jobs and about $750 million per annum for export revenue. Not surprisingly, it is strongly supported by the Commonwealth government. It sounds like a wonderful investment for Western Australia and Australia. I would like to think that Senator Dee Margetts would support it also.

answer.para: It was granted major project facilitation status by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology in January 1996 in view of its potential contribution to the economy. The project has been the subject of a comprehensive environmental impact assessment by Western Australia. It has also been assessed under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, which is our act in respect of approval under the government's foreign investment policy.

Adjacent to that, as I understand it, is the potential port development at Oakajee which will link into the steel processing plant. That is subject to an environmental impact assessment by Western Australia. There are currently no known Commonwealth decisions in regard to the port and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act has in that instance not been triggered.

Nevertheless, I am sure that, provided it meets the highest environmental safeguards, it also would be strongly supported by the Commonwealth government. I read in one of the releases from the Western Australian government that it is being developed pursuant to that government's desire to see development in the Mid West as a centre for value adding and export of the region's natural resources.

It has been pointed out that that region has the potential to become a major industrial area at the cutting edge of modern technology and that Geraldton's future as a significant regional centre providing employment for young people and long-term security for families, while protecting the enviable coastal lifestyle, depends on the proper development of the region's vast wealth of resources. That seems logical to the federal government as well. However, on the issue of Federation funding, the position remains that I do not know of any application from Western Australia for support for that opportunity.

talk.start.para: âBy way of supplementary: at a meeting which was hosted by the Geraldton Chamber of Commerce on 6 March, which I also attended, the Minister for Resources Development, Mr Colin Barnett, stated that the state and Commonwealth `may fund a privately owned and operated port at Oakajee to the tune of $7 or $8 million per annum over the next 10 years'. Can the minister confirm that the federal government is considering subsidising a private port operator in this way? Would such funding be considered consistent with competition policy principles and would such funding trigger the federal Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act? What exactly does `major project facilitation status' mean and when will the government be releasing details of what this means in terms of money and impacts?

âUnfortunately, Madam President, the honourable senator seems to remain confused. Major project facilitation status was given in relation to the An Feng Kingstream Steel Ltd proposal. It has not been given, as I understand it, in relation to the port proposal. It might in the future, I do not know, but it is obviously a very valuable investment.

answer.para: The release by Mr Barnett that I have read said that there will be some small contribution by the Western Australian government, particularly at the feasibility end, but I cannot see in that release any suggestion of a funding request to the Commonwealth government. Whether there is a funding request, whether it will in some way trigger our legislation, is yet to be seen. I am instructed at the moment that no such action has been taken that triggers that legislation.

âThis aspect, I understand, is part of the set of allegations made and is being investigated. I am unable to comment on it at this time. âMy question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Last Thursday night on the ABC's 7.30 Report Senator Bolkus finally admitted leaking the confidential Federal Court affidavit from the Skase case. He said:

Surprise, surprise, those two pages are boxed in the gallery on Monday afternoon.

But even more of a surprise, the two paragraphs that Senator Bolkus quoted from to the media directlyâparagraphs 101 and 109âare marked for the media's attention in the distributed copies. So now we have the affidavit that was given to him by the media being given back to the media marked with the quotes that he had used. âI hear Senator Faulkner interjecting, asking why my office leaked it. He still does not accept that my office never had the affidavit. But we have a video of Senator Bolkus with it in his hand, caught red-handedâ`I cannot give you this but I can read from it off the record'â(Time expired)

âMy question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it true that in a recent study the Australian Taxation Office reported that for small business the wholesale sales tax is, after PAYE taxes, the cheapest of all taxes for business to comply with? Senator Cook interjectingâ

I rise on a matter which I think will probably go down in history as one of the most maladministered and mismanaged messes that this government has created in its two short years of government. Let us get the record straight about what this government is saying. You have to listen to the words very carefully. If you did not, why would Mrs Bishop have given you a briefing at Thredbo about the difficulties she was encountering when she went around Australia, particularly in relation to the defence force personnel spouses, in selling this particular policy of Dr Kemp's? Let us be quite explicit about what is happening here.

The first thing is FLEX 1, which is job matching and that involves, as Senator Newman gave us the usual old run-down, touch screens, et cetera. Dr Kemp says that anybody has access to that. Let me point out to you an example. On Thursday Mrs Lawrence, in the House of Representatives, pointed to an example in Western Australia where somebody was unemployed, not on benefit, wished to apply for a job as a fitter and was told that he would have to pay $220 for thatâjust for being matched to a job. This person was not on benefit, was a retrenched worker and wanted to apply for a job but is told that he would have to pay $220 to do that.

What is unusual about this example? It is illegal in Western Australia to charge for unemployment services. But where it is not illegal it is going to become routine. It is not illegal in Tasmania; it is not illegal in the ACT; it is not illegal in the Northern Territory; and it is not illegal in South Australia. In fact, in South Australia you can be paid retrospectively. That is the story of FLEX 1âthat is, job matchingâyou will have to pay.

Let us move on to what is called FLEX 3âthis is intensive assistance. This is where the weasel words really come out. In fact, Senator Ellison in estimates the other day said, `Dr Kemp has not actually said anything about intensive assistance.' Intensive assistance is what you get if you have been unemployed for 12 months or more. talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Auditor-General's Report No. 35 of 1997-98âPerformance auditâDEETYA International Services: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs highlights yet again another difficulty with that department. While the concept of promoting and expanding export opportunities in the field of education and training is one that I fully support and encourage, I do think that this is, yet again, an opportunity to highlight some difficulties that are emerging with the administration of this portfolio.

It is unfortunate that the problems that the Auditor-General has identified with this particular division are now becoming indicative of a broader problem within DEETYA. What the Auditor has established is that this particular section was not operating successfully in a range of areas which included financial planning, management of risks and cost methodology. As a result of its shortcomings in the way in which this program was administered there seems to be an accumulated cash deficit of $1.4 million.

While that may not be a particularly large sum of money in the context of this department it is nonetheless worthy of note. I want to emphasise that I actually support the expansion and promotion of Australian export opportunities in education. What I do not support, however, is the problems that are now emerging within DEETYA as a direct result of the decline in the resourcing and staffing of this department. It seems to me that the levels of staffing within this department are now such that issues surrounding overall accountability, management and monitoring of programs raise serious concerns within this parliament at large.

DEETYA is not alone when it comes to the problems surrounding these particular matters. This has been highlighted by DEETYA and senior officials of DEETYA itself before the estimates committee last Friday. What has been highlighted there is the inability to keep an accurate track of the spiralling increase in the use of consultancies. In my view, Dr Kemp has to take direct and personal responsibility for this because he has attempted to cover up the extent to which this department has become dependent upon consultants. We have seen the way in which its agencies as well as the department have now used consultants in a very limited period. A small window has opened to us, through which we have been able to establish that some $7 million has been spent on consultants.

We have seen that this department has been gutted by this government. It has lost 80 per cent of its staff. This was the second biggest spending department in government. Its staffing figures, as revealed before the estimates by the secretary to the department, highlight that it has moved from 16,000 people two years ago down to some 2,500 people over the next financial year. This department has been gutted. The situation has now arisen where this government is seeking to spend millions and millions of dollars in consultancies to cover up the failure of this particular portfolio.

What we have here is a government engaged in a callous exercise of job replacement. Thousands of public servants are being shown the door and they are being replaced by consultants at an ever increasing rate of expense to undertake the work that was once done by officers of the department.

The secretary to the department has admitted some embarrassment with regard to the way in which the department itself is not able to maintain its record systems properly any more. He has been able to identify to us that three separate lists of consultants were provided to the estimates committee as a result of questions that I have raised.

The fact remains that the department still has not got it right. For this limited period of time during which we were seeking information, they were not able to distinguish between a consultant and a service provider on a consistent basis. This government has shown that its attempt to use the idea of a service provider has meant some $1 million of the $7 million can be reallocated away from the publicly declared requirements under the annual reporting provisions that are a normal part of public administration into an area which does not require public accountability at the same levels.

What we have seen is an attempt to hide the massive blow-out in consultancies by this government and by this minister, who is engaged in a consultancy binge in an attempt to secure the advice that he wantsânot independent, impartial, analytical advice from a fearless, independent public service but advice that he can control in a manner which is not subject to the normal rigours of the parliamentary system. talk.start.para: âI present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Venezuela and the United States of America which took place between 5 July and 22 July 1997. I seek leave to make some comments.

talk.start.para: âFirst of all, I want to congratulate the staff who wrote the report because it is a good report. The recommendations in the report are mainly from a government perspective, and it is very appropriate that that should be so. They met to inform us about the very serious level of external debt in their countries and the fact that huge debt servicing payments have been made without any reduction in the amount still outstanding because of large interest rates. There were some other solutions that were discussed by this forum of parliamentary members from these other countries. In particular, they raised with us the possibility of debt forgiveness, which did not seem to appeal to many members of the delegation but which is something that I have debated and discussed for a long timeâand I was happy to do that with them.

Another part of our delegation in Venezuela was to visit an Australian embassy sponsored social development project. I have to commend the members of the Australian embassy in Venezuela for their involvement in this. It certainly gives the other side of the picture to the usual fairly glowing reports that we get from delegations about the possibilities of trade, et cetera. What that visit revealed to usâand I need to describe it to the Senateâwas the incredible poverty in a country like Venezuela, which is not a poor country in terms of its resources, its income, its industry, et cetera. Nevertheless, it is a country with incredible poverty.
