The NRS Levy Imposition Bill is the second bill in a package of two bills about NRS funding arrangements.
The NRS Levy Imposition Bill imposes a levy on participating carriers to provide funding for the NRS.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997
The Telecommunications Amendment Bill (No.2) 1997 is the first bill in a package of two bills about NRS funding arrangements.

The Telecommunications Amendment Bill (No.2) 1997 (the Amendment Bill) mostly deals with the operation and funding of the National Relay Service (NRS). The NRS is a service that provides people who are deaf, hearing, or speech impaired, with access to the standard telephone service on terms, and in circumstances, that are comparable to those on which other Australians have access to a standard telephone service.
The Amendment Bill also includes minor amendments to make it clear that:

lines on the customer side of the telecommunications network boundary are not line links so there will be no obligation to hold a carrier licence or arrange for a nominated carrier declaration in relation to these links; and

a carrier that has been declared a nominated carrier over network units that it does not own or operate will be obliged to fulfil carrier related obligations in relation to those network units as though they owned or operated them.

The current contract for the provision of the NRS expires on 30 June 1998. Under the current wording of the Telecommunications Act 1997 from 1 July 1998 the NRS will be brought under all the universal service provisions and funded out of the Universal Service levy on an annual basis at least a year after the service is provided. Only carriers are able to undertake Universal Service provision, because providing these services would necessitate the ownership or operational control of network units.
However, the operation of the NRS is different to Universal Service provision as;
it does not involve the ownership or operation of network units to provide the service to a deaf, hearing, or speech impaired person
provision of the NRS is more like a service provider using existing telecommunications networks to deliver a product to select members of the community that have specific disability needs
NRS provision has been by a small niche operator that is reliant on regular funding.
The intention is that under the bills from 1 July 1998;
the provision of the NRS be open to both carriers and non-carriers
the NRS will be provided by a person, who may or may not be a carrier, under a contract with the Commonwealth; and
the cost of the NRS will be met by carriers in advance on a quarterly basis depending on their eligible revenue or timed traffic.

Publication of NRS cost estimates will enable the carriers to be levied in advance and publication of actual cost figures after the end of the quarter will enable the actual and estimated costs to be reconciled for accuracy. This information with Australian Communications Authority (ACA) participating carrier assessments will determine carrier levy contributions.

Only if a carrier is a participating carrier in relation to the Universal Service Obligation when the ACA calculates levy contributions each quarter and is the subject of the most recent ACA USO levy assessment can the carrier be liable for a levy payment.

The NRS will be provided under a new contract as from 1 July 1998. The proposed amendments require a NRS Service Plan as part of the contract with the NRS provider to include performance standards and timetables for the supply of the service.

As part of the contract the NRS Service Plan will also include how the service will adapt and implement new technology as it becomes available, such as speech to speech for those speech impaired people who find text communications difficult as well as how the NRS provider will conduct the outreach program to promote the service availability to the public, to identify and educate users and potential users.

The ACA will be required to report against the NRS Service Plan in an annual report to the Minister after the end of each financial year. This report will be tabled in both Houses of Parliament. The Minister will also be able to request the ACA to provide advice on the NRS Service Plan at any stage. Changes to the NRS Service Plan can be made through contract negotiations between the NRS provider and the Commonwealth.
Any failure by the NRS provider to comply with the NRS Plan will be addressed in accordance with the NRS contract.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
CHARTER OF BUDGET HONESTY BILL 1996 [No. 2]

The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill is a major structural reform of the way in which this country presents and runs its fiscal policy. The bill fulfils an election promise by this government to make sure that the Australian accounts are presented in a fair and honest manner and to enshrine in legislation a requirement which will govern our government and any future government as to the way in which it will present and improve its financial performance. This is the kind of reform which, when enacted, will be a permanent feature, making sure that Australia's economic policy is run better, making sure that the public is kept better informed, making sure that there is transparency in economic policy in this country.

This is the same bill that was introduced into the House of Representatives on 11 December 1996 and passed by the House of Representatives on 10 February 1997. On 28 October 1997 the Senate passed the bill with ten amendments.
These amendments were unnecessary and made aspects of the bill unworkable.

A number of amendments relate to the arrangements for costing election policies during the caretaker period. They would have made the process non-transparent by allowing the costing of unannounced policies. They would also risk turning the bureaucracy into a research centre for the opposition, inconsistent with the conventions of Westminster Government.

Another amendment sought by the Senate would require a detailed report on threats to the tax system and specific means necessary to counter these threats. This would have drawn attention of tax planners to opportunities for tax avoidance, risking larger revenue losses than would otherwise be the case.
Other amendments to the charter unnecessarily complicated the operation of the bill.

The amendments were not agreed by the House of Representatives and the bill was returned to the Senate. The Senate again insisted on its amendments and on 19 November 1997 the House again rejected those amendments. The bill was then laid aside.

The government is reintroducing this bill because it believes that the people of Australia deserve better fiscal accountability and improved fiscal outcomes. To show our commitment to this, the government has already been complying in full with the charter's requirements.

The need for the bill is clearly demonstrated by the need for improved fiscal outcomes in Australia. There have been persistent Commonwealth budget deficits over the past 25 years. This has led to Commonwealth general government net debt ratcheting up, reaching a little less than 20 per cent of GDP by 1995-96.

The government has been repairing the fiscal mess left by our predecessors. Before we came to office, we were told the budget was in surplus. It was not. It was in deficit to the tune of $10 billion. We inherited that problem. It became our responsibility to fix the mismanagement and the way in which the then government sought to hide it.

As a result of the government's fiscal consolidation program, the budget is expected to move into surplus by 1998-99. Continued surpluses are projected until the turn of the century. This year we are paying off debt. We expect to halve the level of Commonwealth general government debt to around 10 per cent of GDP by the turn of the century.

The bill will help to ensure that the fiscal profligacy of our predecessors is not repeated. It aims to ensure that all future governments are more disciplined, transparent and accountable in operating fiscal policy.

Fiscal discipline will be enhanced by requiring government fiscal policy to be formulated according to principles of sound fiscal management. Transparency and the accountability of government will be substantially increased through improved disclosure of fiscal policy intentions and the regular reporting of information on fiscal developments.

Further, the charter will prevent future governments going to an election on the basis of outdated and misleading information on the fiscal and economic outlook. In short, this bill will ensure that at all times this government and all future governments can be held accountable for their fiscal and economic policies and thereby provide the basis for a sounder economic performance for the economy as a whole, sustainable job opportunities for our people and greater accountability of government to the electors whom they serve.
I would like to highlight some of the main features of the fiscal framework that will be established by the bill.

The bill will reform fiscal policy formulation through introducing principles for the sound management of fiscal policy against which governments must develop their fiscal strategy. These principles will focus attention on a range of issues that must be addressed if fiscal policy is to be sustainable over time.

The principles take account of the need to address short-term issues, such as cyclical economic downturns, while recognising the importance of medium-term issues such as the sustainability of government debt and national saving. The presentation of a government fiscal strategy as required by the bill will also increase public awareness of a government's objectives and establish a benchmark for evaluating fiscal performance.

The charter of budget honesty will also ensure that up-to-date information is available so that a government's performance can be assessed against its fiscal objectives. To achieve this, the bill establishes a formal reporting structure. With each year's budget, a report will be released setting out economic and fiscal projections for the budget year and three forward years. These projections will illustrate the consequences of the adopted fiscal strategy.

A further report released midway through the financial year will update the fiscal and economic projections contained in the budget report. The details of fiscal outcomes for the just completed financial year will be presented in a report to be released within three months of the end of that financial year. In addition, an intergenerational report will be produced every five years to report on the long-term sustainability of current fiscal policies.

These reports will provide fundamental information that will allow government performance to be assessed against the objectives set out in the fiscal strategy statement. However, the bill also gives particular attention to ensuring that important fiscal information is available during the election period.

In doing that, we want to make sure that no other government in future behaves in the way in which the Labor government behaved in the March 1996 election. They hid the true state of the books. That is why we intend to make it incumbent for a full and open report to be made about the financial state of the books at the opening of an election campaign and not to be found out by whichever government wins at the close.

The bill requires the secretaries to the Treasury and the Department of Finance to prepare a pre-election report providing an updated assessment of the fiscal and economic outlook. Never again will a government go to an election without the public being aware of the current economic and fiscal situation. Never again will the deception attempted by the Labor Party in the last election be allowed if this legislation is enacted.

In addition, the bill provides for more equal access to Treasury and Finance costings of election commitments by the government and the opposition during the caretaker period. This will allow the electorate to be better informed of the financial implications of election commitments.

These provisions are fair and balanced and consistent with the principles of Westminster Government. The amendments to these arrangements that had been sought by the opposition are non-transparent and unworkable.

In conclusion, the government believes that the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 represents a landmark development in the conduct of fiscal policy and reporting of fiscal outcomes. It is the kind of reform which, when enacted, will change: the way in which elections are conducted; the way in which policies are implemented; the way in which future generations are brought into consideration in economic decision making; and our economic policy for the better.

The bill will provide a strong impetus towards achieving better fiscal outcomes by providing greater discipline in policy formulation, regular statements of fiscal objectives and increased accountability for fiscal performance.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997
This bill proposes to amend the National Health Act 1953, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.
The amendments will give effect to a part of the Government's package of reforms to private health insurance. The reforms contained in this bill will:
. engender a positive and competitive environment in the private health sector;
. reduce some of the cost pressures on health insurance premiums;
. make contracting more attractive between the various parties; and
. help consumers by reducing the problem of often large and unexpected out-of-pocket expenses and multiple medical bills.

Private health insurance has been the subject of inquiries by the Industry Commission and the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee. The package of reforms contained in this bill responds to those recommendations requiring legislation that could be dealt with immediately and incorporates the reforms announced by the Government on 19 August 1997.

The Commission also made a number of recommendations that require further analysis and development. The most important of these is unfunded lifetime community rating which the Government is now examining to determine its feasibility.
Unfunded lifetime community rating is designed to balance the age distribution of fund membership, lower premiums and make private health insurance more affordable for young and old alike.

There are also reforms that do not require legislation. The Government has decided to establish a second tier default benefit which would apply where there is no contract between a private hospital and a fund, but where the hospital has in place arrangements for informed financial consent and simplified billing, and evidence of an appropriate level of treatment.

Australians overwhelmingly support Medicare and the universal access to public health services that this entails. Yet at the same time, over one third of the population still has some form of private health insurance.

Clearly, we have a universally available public health system which is highly valued by most Australians, but also a significant number of people who see value in having access to the private health sector.

The Government sees such a choice as a legitimate aspiration and understands that the key for most Australians to such access remains private health insurance. Approximately 80 per cent of private hospital episodes are funded through private health insurance.

This Government has a focus on the total health systemâpublic and private. The private hospital system is an essential ingredient in the nation's health care mix. The community needs to have access to the existing range of beds and services across both the public and private sectors.

And it is a matter of common sense to maximise the use of our existing acute capital stockâboth public and privateârather than simply commit billions of extra dollars to funding new public hospital beds.

The Government's message is loud and clear: that the private sector is a vital complement to the long term viability of Medicare and the public hospital system. Importantly, this is not just idle rhetoric. Active and positive steps are being taken to ensure that private health insurance is a realistic choice for those Australians who wish to maintain it.

This bill introduces reforms to private health insurance that build on the Government's Private Health Insurance Incentives Scheme and the adjustments to the Medicare levy for people on higher incomes who have chosen not to insure themselves privately.
I will now outline the main elements of the reform package.
The first set of reforms will make contracting between funds, hospitals and doctors more attractive.

The private health insurance legislation introduced by the previous Government relied on contracting between funds and doctors to address a number of issues affecting private health insuranceâincluding the incidence of unknown out of pocket costs. This legislation has been a spectacular failure with only a handful of doctors prepared to enter contracts. The result is that consumers have continued to experience often large and unanticipated out-of-pocket medical bills.

Nonetheless, it is vital that we achieve greater certainty for consumers, either through informed financial consent so that they know in advance the out-of-pocket costs or even better by securing agreements for 100 percent cover for their medical bills.

Schedule 3 Paragraphs 5, 6 and 7 will for the first time allow health funds to pay medical benefits above the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) to doctors who have Practitioner Agreements with private hospitals. And, as is currently the case, Practitioner Agreements will only be permitted where the hospital also has a fixed cost contract known as a Hospital Purchaser Provider Agreement with the fund.
The effect of these new arrangements will be either to exclude out-of-pocket costs altogether or allow for a pre determined amount to be borne by the patient.

The level of payment for in-hospital medical services will be negotiated between the hospital and the doctor concerned. Such payment may be on whatever basis hospitals and doctors choose. For example, a percentage of the MBS fee, a retainer or some other agreed block payment.

Where doctors have Practitioner Agreements, this bill enables the 75 per cent Medicare benefit to be paid direct to the health fund. In these circumstances, assignment of the Medicare benefit by the patient to the fund will be mandatory. This will greatly simplify the billing and claiming process for patients.

In other words, doctors will no longer have to negotiate only with the fundsâa key objection that the medical profession has raised and steadfastly maintained since 1994. Agreements will be negotiated by the people directly involved in providing care to patients, who will then be able to provide services for no or known out-of-pocket costs and with greatly simplified billing and claiming procedures for the patient.

Furthermore, Schedule 3 Paragraph 4 will require all agreements offered by funds or hospitals to include a clause guaranteeing the general professional freedom of doctors to identify the appropriate treatment for their patients within the scope of accepted clinical practice. With the exception of the price arrangements entered into by the parties which will remain commercial-in-confidence and information relating to individuals, the agreements will be open to public scrutiny.

The medical profession has consistently said that their objection to such agreements was based on concerns about US-style managed care, where funds have used their market power to dictate and limit clinical decisions.
With the threat of US-style managed care removed from the equation I am confident that doctors will be more willing to negotiate arrangements with private hospitals.

I would hope that the profession sensibly understands that their cooperation is absolutely essential if the private health care sector is to remain viable, which depends largely on private health insurance continuing to cover a large proportion of the population.
The second set of amendments removes unnecessary costs on funds, improves the regulatory environment and makes refinements to existing legislation to improve the operation of the industry.

Schedule 1 will tighten the definition of health insurance business to reduce the potential for new products entering the market to undermine the Government's commitment to community rating. Products have beenâand many more could beâdesigned which are risk rated, but effectively provide health insurance by extending the number and range of conditions drawing on the model of trauma insurance and basing payments on estimated hospital and medical costs. The changes to the legislation will make it clearer that products of this nature cannot be marketed other than as community rated health insurance, while leaving legitimate trauma and life products in place.

Schedule 2 replaces the provision requiring payment of benefits at an acute rate for the first 35 days of hospitalisation, irrespective of whether acute care is provided. The ensuing regulation will provide for a determination of benefits for nursing home type patients at an appropriate level and structure.

The Productivity Commission could see no sound economic basis for payment of higher acute care benefits for nursing home type patients. This adds an unnecessary cost burden to health funds and therefore adds to the cost pressures leading to increases in premium levels. This situation has arisen because of a rigidity in the National Health Act which obliges health funds to pay an acute care rate for these patients irrespective of the need for acute care for the first thirty five days. This bill will remove the rigidity in the act and replace it with a regulatory power which will allow the development of more flexible administrative and payment structures for nursing home type patients.
Schedule 4 will allow changes to reinsurance arrangements to be made by disallowable instrument and facilitate necessary changes to reinsurance that may become necessary in the future.

Schedule 5 restructures the Private Health Insurance Administration Council with a new board independent of the Department of Health and Family Services and the industry. It will include a Commissioner and two to four other individuals as recommended by the Industry Commission.

Schedule 6 contains a number of measures that will assist the Private Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner to provide an effective and efficient operation over the next few years by which time information will be available to assess whether more substantial powers are required. The Commis sioner will also be renamed the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman.

Schedule 7 Paragraphs 2 and 3 extend the maximum waiting period for obstetrics from nine to 12 months. Obstetrics has been an area where "hit and run" behaviour is purportedly severe. Extending the waiting period to 12 months will help to reduce some of the cost pressures faced the health insurance industry.

Schedule 8 will allow the assignment of Medicare payments for in-hospital medical treatment by the patient to another party as part of approved simplified billing arrangements. This will encourage the development of simplified billing arrangements for patients treated by doctors not covered by agreements with either health funds or hospitals.

Schedule 11 Paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 will make it clear that for-profit organisations are on the same footing as not-for-profit organisations in terms of applying for registration as a health fund and facilitate the transition of existing non-profit funds to for-profit status if that is their desire.

The reforms in this bill have the potential to create an environment which is not only more attractive to new players but also to consumers through the development of health insurance products that truly offer value for money. They also form part of a comprehensive package of related measures to make the most of our existing health care assets, both public and private, and to ensure that Australians can look forward confidently to assured quality health care.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

This bill makes amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 and consequential amendments to the Customs Act 1901. The changes to therapeutic goods legislation include measures designed to improve the operating environment for the Australian pharmaceutical industry, as well as ensure the availability of new drugs, while enhancing Australia's commitment to its international obligations under the WTO Agreement on Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights. This will be achieved through the introduction of a new data protection scheme for new chemical entities, referred to as "active components" in the amending legislation.

At present confidential information submitted to the Therapeutic Goods Administration in connection with applications to register products in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods is protected against disclosure, unless release is in the public interest, and also against use by the TGA for its own commercial benefit. Under the new "data protection" scheme to be introduced by the bill, this data will now have five years of "data protection". During this time, any other company seeking to register a generic copy of the registered product containing, or consisting of, the active component will be required to seek the agreement of the originator company before the TGA can directly or indirectly access or reference the originator company's data relating to the same active component.

Applicants seeking to register generic products containing protected active components may still do so. However, they must develop and lodge their own full data package, instead of lodging an abbreviated package that demonstrates bioequivalence with a new active component. Most products that have a new active component will attract separate protection under a patent during their first five years on the market, but the "data protection" regime will provide a safety net for those products which may fall outside the norm.

The "data protection" measures are in line with those provided by the United States, the European Union and New Zealand, and the Government's decision to introduce these measures follows a review by the Government of Australia's international obligations in relation to registration data, undertaken in response to the Industry Commission's Report No. 51 (1996) , The Pharmaceutical Industry. The Commission reported that "there is potential for the availability of important new drugs to be jeopardised in the event Australia's current practice relating to confidential information does not meet its international obligations."

Provisions have also been included in the bill to close off a loophole in the current act that would enable, for example, a person who consistently fails to meet manufacturing standards and commits offences against the act to continue to manufacture goods, simply by applying for manufacturing licences through other entities such as companies. Thus, Item 6 inserts a provision that will enable the Secretary to prevent persons in control of another licensee convicted of an offence against the Therapeutic Goods Act, or a law of a State or Territory in relation to therapeutic goods, from immediately applying for and obtaining another manufacturing licence through another person, such as a new or different company. The amendment makes additions to the existing grounds for refusing to issue a manufacturing licence, and the same grounds would provide the basis for cancelling a licensee's manufacturing licence.

Regulation-making powers have been conferred upon the Governor-General to enable the administrative functions associated with the issue of import and export permits and licences which are to be exercised by the Secretary of the Department of Health and Family Services to be prescribed under therapeutic goods legislation. The remaining functions will stay under Customs legislation.

The amendments to the Customs Act 1901 take into account the Governor-General's powers to make similar regulations under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 for the grant of import or export permits and licences for therapeutic goods that remain prohibited imports or exports under Customs legislation.

This will facilitate a more efficient and responsive regulation and the development of a risk management approach which maintains Australia's obligations under the three United Nations Treaties aimed at preventing illicit drug trafficking and drug abuse, while reducing the regulatory burden on industry.

Other measures included in the bill relate to the power of the Secretary to seek the same kind of information about the manufacturing processes used for the manufacture of listable therapeutic goods as for registrable goods. The more detailed information will better equip the Secretary to determine whether or not listable goods are suitable for inclusion in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, and whether they should remain there.
Overall, this bill will benefit Australia's therapeutic industry and further enhance Australia's role as a leader in drug regulation.

talk.start.para: âDefence support is now one of the four major industries of the Northern Territory. At a time of increasing political instability, it is salutary to focus on our defence assets in northern Australia. The Army Presence in the North project, the APIN project, stems from the 1987 defence white paper, Defence of Australia , and commenced in 1992 with the relocation of an armoured reconnaissance regiment to Darwin. It is a task of national importance and will significantly change the thrust of Australia's defence, particularly with the emphasis and priority given in recent years by the Howard government and the ministers Ian McLachlan and Bronwyn Bishop.

speech.para: APIN involves the relocation to Darwin of approximately 2,300 personnel, 200 armoured fighting vehicles, including Leopard tanks, ASLAV light armoured vehicles and M113 armoured personnel carriers and 500 support vehicles. A total of $850 million is to be spent on infrastructure development and relocation activities over the 10-year period from 1992. By the year 2001, Australian Defence Force numbers in the Northern Territory will stand at over 4,400. The total Defence Force `family', including dependants, will number well in excess of 10,000 people.

In addition to APIN, there are many other exciting defence related activities taking place in the Northern Territory that will have a significant beneficial impact on the local economy and population, which I will get to shortly. Major focuses for APIN in 1998 include the completion of APIN stage 1, which is scheduled to be completed in the first half of 1998. This will see capital works costing $198 million finished, with most of the work completed at Robertson Barracks. APIN stage 1 includes new or additional facilities being built for the following units: Headquarters 1st Brigade, 1st Armoured Regiment of the Royal Australian Armoured Corps, 104th Signal Squadron of the Royal Australian Signals, the 161st Reconnaissance Squadron, Headquarters Army Support Unit Darwin and the 7th Training Group. There will be some additional facilities for the 2nd Cavalry Regiment.

There will also be the important opening in May 1998 of a 70-place defence child-care facility at Fairway Waters, a suburb of Palmerston, greatly expanding child-care places available to all Palmerston residents. Palmerston is now the fastest growing town in Australia. It is adjacent to Robertson Barracks and is a satellite city in its own right of Darwin.

APIN stage 2, which will cost $268 million, is proceeding and expected to take until the year 2000 or 2001 to complete. In 1998 there will be the biggest single move north under APIN. The 5th/7th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment of the 1st Brigade, will be relocated from Sydney to Darwin. As the mechanised infantry battalion of the 1st Brigade, 5/7 RAR is a key component and is the largest unit in the brigade. It has a current strength of 518 soldiers and is not expected to exceed 540 this year.

Due to the fact that 5/7 RAR is a combat unit, it is an all male organisation and currently comprises 326 single soldiers and 192 married members. Approximately 675 dependants will be moving to Darwin with the soldiers of the 5/7 RAR. This important link and relocation is very important because Territorians have embraced this integration of defence families into the social infrastructure of the community, and the extra residents and expenditure they generate underpin programs in housing, health, education and recreation. I know and can say confidently that Territorians openly welcome ADF personnel and their families into the community. Additionally, the capital works program spending of $143 million this year is very much alive. Additionally, we have the participation of personnel in defence exercises.

Based on these figures, a total of almost 1,200 people will be moving to Darwin and Palmerston in late 1998 and early 1999. Defence has worked very hard to ensure that the move will go as smoothly as possible and that integration takes place carefully. With the experience to draw on the move north of the 1st Armoured Regiment and the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, Defence do not anticipate any problems and there is excellent cooperation with the Northern Territory Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry, in particular their Defence and Space Industries Group.

The Australian Defence Force will also ensure, through a community integration committee, that people will assimilate well into the community. It is a credit to the Northern Territory government that it is the first state government to create a ministry of defence support, and I note it is held by the Chief Minister. The Defence Force realises the importance of a soldier's family settling in and is taking great lengths to make sure this happens in the Top End.

In 1998 infrastructure developments will be extended and relate to fields such as the Bradshaw Field Training Area. Fifty-four million dollars has been approved to develop Bradshaw, an 8,710 square kilometre property 600 kilometres south-west of Darwin, into a live fire and manoeuvring area to be used primarily by 1st Brigade. Approximately $14 million will be spent in 1998 on Bradshaw, with the remainder being spent through to the year 2000.

At RAAF Darwin expenditure of $10 million this financial year will take place. This will see work continue on the $60 million development of operational facilities that include the provision of ordnance loading aprons for 10 FA18 or F111 aircraft, an operational and technical support facility, a base command post, additional fuel storage, a rescue and firefighting facility, and associated civil works and engineering services.

At RAAF Tindal, whose personnel did such an excellent job recently in the Katherine flood disaster, work on stage 4 of development will proceed. About $13.5 million will be spent this year out of a budget of $31 million for the whole of stage 4. This will see the completion of facilities much like those described for RAAF Base Darwin with additional deployment accommodation and apron extensions. In Alice Springs a tremendous amount of work is being carried on for infrastructure development associated with the joint defence facility of Pine Gap. Total defence capital works spending in the Territory for 1997-98 is $143 million, an increase of $37 million over 1996-97 and a significant part of the annual defence expenditure of $385 million for the 1997-98 financial year.

The Defence Force's annual program of exercises will also take place, and personnel from Australia, New Zealand, the United States, Singapore and Indonesia will participate in Australian Defence Force exercises in the Northern Territory. It is estimated that some 5,500 personnel will take part in exercises in 1998 and approximately half will be ADF personnel not normally based in the Northern Territoryâa complementary exercise to Northern Territory tourism. This is another boost of tens of millions of dollars into the Northern Territory economy.
In 1999, Exercise Crocodile 99, a replacement for the Kangaroo exercises, will take place in the Territory. Planning has commenced for this very significant operation.

There is also significant economic benefit for Darwin and the rest of the Territory derived from visiting warships. Already this year six large vessels have stopped over in Darwin. These have included USS Peleliu, USS Juneau, USS Blue Ridge, USS Fife, USS Port Royal and USS Curtis Wilbur. They carried in total over 5,300 sailors, and the length of their stays varied from a couple of days to a week. At a very conservative estimate, these visits have injected $5 million into the Northern Territory economy.

I believe the importance of defence to the Northern Territory cannot be overstated. I have described many examples in 1998 alone which will result in massive injections of cash and capital works into the Territory economy. There is also the fact that ADF personnel are now an integral part of the Territory's communities. I think it could safely be said that in past years many defence personnel based in the Territory left their hearts down south and returned to what they viewed as home after their stint in the north was finished. I do not believe this is now the case.

The extension of time of people living in the north will be a credit to both the Defence Force and the Territory community. The majority of ADF personnel based in the Territory are there for the long term, and I believe they will view the Territory always as home. Their unstinting and selfless service in the Katherine flood disaster shows just how much a part of the community the ADF have become.

But he put it in there to beat the unions, not to protect them. He finalised a plan to override that basic rightâthe right of labour to organiseâwithin weeks of the legislation being passed. That plan is to sack one work force and replace it with another before the commission could move to protect the rights of the sacked workers. The Reith plan requires a trained work force waiting in the wings. Let me quote from a minute to Mr Reith from his department, a minute that appears to reflect the work done by a number of consultants, starting with Mr David Trebeck. It states:

What would be needed for the MUA's influence on the waterfront to be significantly weakened would be for a range of affected service users and providers to take decisive action to protect or advance their interests.
It then goes on:

Stevedores would need to activate well prepared strategies to dismiss their work force, and replace them with another, quickly, in a way that limited the prospect of, for example, the Commission ordering reinstatement of the current work force.

This is a key part of the Reith strategy. Without a new trained up work force, the plan would not work, would it. The failed Dubai exercise was the first failed attempt to implement this part of Mr Reith's plan by Mr Corrigan. When Mr Reith said he knew nothing of Dubai, what he was saying was that he did not know where the training was going on, not that he knew nothing about the strategy.

The strategy was agreed by the government in February last year and progressively refined through a number of consultancies. It is a plan designed specifically to dispose of workers because they are members of a union. Therefore it is a plan in breach of section 298A of the Workplace Relations Actâthe freedom of association provision. In this plan, Patricks and Mr Corrigan were only lieutenants in the exercise. That company sought to implement that key part of the Reith plan in Dubai via Hong Kong. It failed. But the NFF is now the lieutenant attempting to do the same thing at Webb dock. They are also simply attempting to implement part of Mr Reith's strategy.

There is little doubt that the waterfront needs further reform. There is little doubt that the whole transport chain needs further reform. It was the former government who, with the support of the employers and their workers, made significant gains. That momentum was lost in March 1996, when the agenda switched from economic reform to a political campaign to smash organised labour in this country.

The public benefit of this political exercise has been put in context by a major user of the dock. This is the information that I have which I think completely refutes the argument that this government is putting about this particular exercise on the docks. The cost of stevedoring is around two per cent of total transport costs for a major user of the Melbourne docks and 0.2 of one per cent of the value of a container. That is the impact of stevedoring costs on the cost of a ship containerâ0.2 of one per cent. It is this company's view that the cost to the economy of the government's confrontationist approach to achieve a political outcome on the waterfront far outweighs the perceived economic benefits. I agree with that assessment.

What we have here is a risk strategy in breach of the government's own legislation which will not make the savings that have been suggested. I know that Minister Reith has suggested that the cost of moving a container across the Melbourne waterfront is $200. That might well be the case in isolated examples. But for regular users, contract users, of the waterfront the actual cost is significantly less than that. For the company that I have been in contact with, the actual cost per container is not half of the $200ânot $100âbut $70. If there is a suggestion that you can reduce the cost from $200 to $100 per container by this exercise that is being implemented by the National Farmers Federation, in fact the real cost now is 30 per cent lower to this particular user than the cost which is being touted as the savings cost which will result from the so-called reform on the waterfront.

So the argument that is being put forward, the public face of this exercise that is being put forwardâthe public face that I suggest is being developed by pollster Mr Mark Textor and refined by strategist Mr Jonathan Gaul, arising from ACIL consultanciesâis based on non-fact and on an isolated and false example of the true cost of shipping containers across the waterfront. That is the very basis of this campaignâgive out as much misleading information as you can, portray the work force in a particular way, pretend that the costs are higher than they really are and that savings are available. If the costs were that high they would be.

The reality is that the real costs on the Melbourne waterfront of shipping a container for regular users is as low as $70 per container. If that is the truthâand I suggest it is because that is the information I have from a regular userâthen Mr Reith had better set the record straight. He better step in to the parliament tomorrow and tell the parliament that, in reality, the costs to users of the Australian waterfront are significantly lower than the costs he suggested apply and that the savings that are available have already been achieved and were achieved by the WIRA reform of the previous Labor government.

talk.start.para: âTonight I wish to place on record some of the concerns that the Australian Democrats have with the tendering out of employment services in this countryâin particular, our fear that the government has established an anti-competitive market designed to fatten up Employment National, which received the largest share of the overall market, for future privatisation. Indeed, some of this debate took place in taking note of answers after question time today. I certainly got more carried away with some of the interjections and I was not able to confine my remarks to some of the extraneous issues at hand, so I seek to do so now.

speech.para: The government has repeatedly assured and asserted to this chamber and to the community that, despite copious evidence, I believe, to the contrary, the unemployed in Australia will be better off under the new arrangements under this particular new scheme. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) has claimed that there will be a greater choice of service providers available to the unemployed. This, so far, has appeared manifestly untrue. The number of providers of employment services to the disadvantaged has in fact fallen by around 61 per cent, I believe, to only 125 providers.

One only needs to look at Lismore as an example, an area which had six sites providing case management services. As of 1 May, there will be only one site providing case management services, and that will be occupied by Employment National. We see that replicated in Grafton where the only provider of case management is, again, Employment National. So, far from promoting choice, the government has actually imposed its own monopoly in a number of towns and areas.

The government, I note, has also sought to perpetuate the view that there will be greater access to services under the new scheme. I found it very hard to see how the government can maintain such a view, given that the number of sites where the long-term unemployed can get intensive training to prepare them for work has actually fallen from 869 to 715âa drop of around 18 per cent. St Mary's, an area with one of Sydney's highest unemployment rates, will see its two local groups servicing 600 people replaced by one company with a contract to serve just 110 people.

The government has also asserted that services will improve under the new system. We are still wondering how this is actually going to be achieved, or how this can be the case. The inappropriate nature of many of the awards, whereby many organisations receive contracts for work in areas and in fields in which they have no previous or little experience or in areas where they have no record of operation, means that unemployed people face being assisted by inexperienced staff.

It is a sad fact indeed that in the last week we have seen an embarrassing number of examples of awards being brought to the public's attentionâobviously, in this place and in the media as well. Organisations specialising in the provision of services to Aboriginal people, the disabled, ex-offenders and the long-term unemployed have been overlooked in favour of organisations which, in some cases, have little or no experience. I gave the case today in my home state of South Australia where the Offenders Aid & Rehabilitation Services of South Australia Inc. received contracts for FLEX 1 and FLEX 2 services but not for FLEX 3, which was actually its area of expertise. The Gold Coast company Leonie Green & Associates won two contracts in Botany and Chatswood even though it has never operated in Sydney.

So, despite the evidence of expertise and experience presented by tenderers to the government, it would appear that the more established and the more successful the organisation the less likely it was to actually be awarded a contract. The highly successful skillshare program, which has been debated and discussed on many occasions in this place, has seen just 50 out of its 300 service providers retain funding. In some cases, I wonder how they are going to remain financially or economically viable. My understanding is that, in its last year of operation, skillshare provided something like 60,000 placements. It had a very high comparable record of success. I think it is shameful that only 50 out of 300 service providers have retained their funding.

The failure of many of the small organisations to win contracts has also resulted in the loss of community links and local expertise that you build up over the years of service in a particular area, and which are unlikely, certainly at this stage, to be replicated by organisations which have never operated in that location.

There are also serious concerns that a number of the successful tenderers will not be ready by the starting date, by 1 May, as they are having to advertise for specialist staff, establish offices in new areas or subcontract out work. We have heard a number of cases presented to this placeâand one particularly infamous case nowâwhere this is the case. They simply cannot do this in the remaining six weeks. I ask the government how they envisage that in the next six weeks these particular arrangements will be put in place so that these providers meet their starting date requirements. In light of these issues, it is clear that the government's claim that the new system will see improvements in choice, access and services for the unemployed are demonstrably false, or certainly it will be a challenge to meet those claims.

We believe the government has been somewhat cavalier in its treatment of service providers. Many small businesses that have been providing invaluable services to the unemployed and the community as a whole will go under as a result of having been ignored by the government. A significant proportion of successful tenderers have been awarded contracts which are not for what they tendered for. They are not necessarily financially viable and we will see them struggling to compete against Employment National.

Many tendering organisations expected to be able to cross-subsidise their provision of FLEX 1 and FLEX 2 services with FLEX 3 work, yet a surprising amount of the latter work has been concentrated in the hands of only five organisations, most notably Employment National and Drake International. Employment National has been awarded 42 per cent of the FLEX 3 case management work, which represents around $700 million of the $1.7 billion allocated to this scheme. By any measure this disproportionality is inappropriate and raises serious questions about the motives underlying the tendering process.

The Democrats would like to know why organisations with previous expertise and experience lost out to organisations with little or no capacity to deliver the services for which they were contracted and why Employment National was awarded a disproportionate amount of the most lucrative work at the expense, in many cases, of the smaller providers. We believe that Employment National has been handed the employment market on a plate. We will continue to call on the minister to explain why this is so and to provide, hopefully, an assurance that the government is not merely fattening up Employment National for future privatisation.

We believe that the government's disregard for probity in its tendering processes and its repeated assertions that things are somehow going to get better under its new scheme and that everything is going to be in place to run like a well-oiled machine by 1 May are contrary to clear evidence that shows the government's contempt for service providers, the unemployed and, in this case, due process.
